ratings.comment: I took 300 with Neil during the summer time. It was nice because he chopped off a few days from class to give us more time to work on our final paper (which is an ethnographic exercise). I say that it was nice because all we did everyday was watch crappy old educational movies from the 70s and 80s. I was bothered by the smell of cigarette smoke :(

kind-of represents the "dark side" of anthropology (by "dark" i mean ambiguous/gray/ethically relative), which is great. his classes gave a good balance to my other activist, human rights-based anthro courses.
show up. hand in final paper. get A. love this prof.
Neil was my favorite professor at UW Madison!

first of all, anthro 100 is hardly difficult regardless of who teaches it. if you got lower than a B in that class consider yourself: a)lazy b)an idiot c)both a and c. profs have more interest in classes that are not mindless intro courses; therefore, whitehead is not to blame for seeming aloof at times. in fact, he's really quite a good prof.

I don't think he cared at all about teaching Anthro 100. He just slapped the books on us and showed us a video every other class. His lectures were stream of conscious and confusing. I'm sure he'd be a great teacher for any other class (he had that potential), but beware if you get him for Anthro 100. If so, read the books!!!

I really enjoyed this class even though it was different than what I expected.  It was team taught and of the two profs, while Whitehead talked a lot, he didn't coddle us like Wofford did.  He lets you do your own thing for the term paper and allows you to talk in class if you want to, but doesn't insist upon it.  I really liked this class.
I couldn't understand a thing he said and what he did say was irrelevant. Very hard to take any notes off of what he said. There was a TON of reading and the test was very random.
Lecture's were so disorganized and unclear. He tests almost exclusively from the books and there's tons to read. Didn't like his section of the course...

I love this guy!  The way this class was run was awesome.  getting to discuss things with a prof instead of just having a lecture every week was really cool.  also, hearing the opinions of everyone in the class and everyone's comments on the topics was really neat.  great prof and interesting class.
One of the best professors that I had in college.  I would love to post a long praise for him, but I'm limited to 256 characters!

For the class, he isn't that great, but then again, the class itself isn't that great or even well organized. However, the man knows what he is talking about. Go talk to him, don't be intimidated by his british accent, he certainly is interesting and full of knowledge.

This professor opens your mind to possibilities you have NEVER considered. He makes you rethink how and why violence occurs and the functional aspects of war. This is a "must-take", especially since we are at war right now.
